evidence.dc:description: Used western blotting analysis to determine the expression of the TMIE protein in the cochlea. They used C57BL/6J mice and found that Tmie protein expression is increased in postnatal develpmental stages. Relative to its expression in other tissues.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Loss-of function mutations in the transmembrane inner ear expressed (Tmie/TMIE) gene have been shown to cause deafness in mice and humans (DFNB6). Previous studies report that the circling mouse can be an animal model for DFNB6. However, the expression pattern of Tmie protein in postnatal developmental stages has not been clearly revealed. In this study we tried to investigate the expression of Tmie protein in the liver, spleen, kidney, and lung, as well as in the cochlea. We examined various tissue samples from five different age groups of C57BL/6J animals. Using western blotting analysis, the expression of Tmie protein in these organs has been identified. The results show that Tmie protein expression in the cochlea has been increased in postnatal developmental stages, indicating that Tmie plays an important role in not only the development and also in the function of the cochlea. The expression pattern of Tmie in adult mouse organs such as the liver, spleen, kidney, and spleen significantly vary in adult rats. The order of Tmie expression level in mice (63 days after birth) was spleen, liver, lung, cochlea, and kidney, whereas in the adult rat it was liver, cochlea, lung, spleen, and kidney.
dc:source.dc:creator: Karuppasamy S
dc:source.dc:title: Expression of deafness protein Tmie in postnatal developmental stages of C57BL/6J mice.

evidence.rdfs:label: C57BL/6J Cochlear Expression

evidence.dc:description: Used PCR to confirm the genotypes of the mouse and the deletion of the portion of TMIE in the spinner mouse. Also, used northern blot to show expression of TMIE in different tissues and a RT-PCR to demonstrate expression in the cochlea of mice.

dc:source.dc:abstract: The recessive mutation at the mouse spinner (sr) locus results in hearing loss and vestibular dysfunction due to neuroepithelial defects in the inner ear. Using a positional cloning strategy, we have identified the mutant locus responsible for this pathology. The affected gene (Tmie) lies within a 40 kb deletion in the original sr allele. In a newly identified allele, Tmie contains a nonsense mutation expected to truncate the C-terminal end of its product. The 153 amino acid protein encoded by the gene shows no similarity to other known proteins, and is predicted to contain a signal peptide and at least one transmembrane domain. Tmie transcripts were identified in several tissues, including the cochlea. Loss of function of Tmie results in postnatal alterations of sensory hair cells in the cochlea, including defects in stereocilia, the apical projections of hair cells that are important in mechanotransduction of sound. These morphological defects are associated with a profound failure to develop normal auditory function. Consistent with a conserved role for this gene in the cochlea, the genetic mapping data presented here support human TMIE as the gene affected at DFNB6, a non-syndromic hearing loss locus. The spinner mutant is thus a valuable model for insight into mechanisms of human deafness and development of sensory cell function.
dc:source.dc:creator: Mitchem KL
dc:source.dc:title: Mutation of the novel gene Tmie results in sensory cell defects in the inner ear of spinner, a mouse model of human hearing loss DFNB6.

evidence.rdfs:label: Northern Blot of TMIE expression in Cochlea of mice

evidence.dc:description: Transmembrane protein TMIE forms a ternary complex with the tip-link component PCDH15 and its binding partner TMHS/LHFPL5. Alternative splicing of the PCDH15 cytoplasmic domain regulates formation of this ternary complex. Transducer currents are abolished by a homozygous Tmie-null mutation, and subtle Tmie mutations that disrupt interactions between TMIE and tip links affect transduction, suggesting that TMIE is an essential component of the hair cell’s mechanotransduction machinery that functionally couples the tip link to the transduction channel. The multisubunit composition of the transduction complex and the regulation of complex assembly by alternative splicing is likely critical for regulating channel properties in different hair cells and along the cochlea’s tonotopic axis.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Hair cells are the mechanosensory cells of the inner ear. Mechanotransduction channels in hair cells are gated by tip links. The molecules that connect tip links to transduction channels are not known. Here we show that the transmembrane protein TMIE forms a ternary complex with the tip-link component PCDH15 and its binding partner TMHS/LHFPL5. Alternative splicing of the PCDH15 cytoplasmic domain regulates formation of this ternary complex. Transducer currents are abolished by a homozygous Tmie-null mutation, and subtle Tmie mutations that disrupt interactions between TMIE and tip links affect transduction, suggesting that TMIE is an essential component of the hair cell's mechanotransduction machinery that functionally couples the tip link to the transduction channel. The multisubunit composition of the transduction complex and the regulation of complex assembly by alternative splicing is likely critical for regulating channel properties in different hair cells and along the cochlea's tonotopic axis.
dc:source.dc:creator: Zhao B
dc:source.dc:title: TMIE is an essential component of the mechanotransduction machinery of cochlear hair cells.

evidence.rdfs:label: TMIE mechanotransduction interaction partners

evidence.dc:description: Mechanotransduction is important for cochlear hair cell function, and the evidence in this paper suggests that hearing impairment is a direct consequence of limited mechanoelectrical transduction caused by TMIE deficiency.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Little is known about the proteins that mediate mechanoelectrical transduction, the process by which acoustic and accelerational stimuli are transformed by hair cells of the inner ear into electrical signals. In our search for molecules involved in mechanotransduction, we discovered a line of deaf and uncoordinated zebrafish with defective hair-cell function. The hair cells of mutant larvae fail to incorporate fluorophores that normally traverse the transduction channels and their ears lack microphonic potentials in response to vibratory stimuli. Hair cells in the posterior lateral lines of mutants contain numerous lysosomes and have short, disordered hair bundles. Their stereocilia lack two components of the transduction apparatus, tip links and insertional plaques. Positional cloning revealed an early frameshift mutation in tmie, the zebrafish ortholog of the mammalian gene transmembrane inner ear. The mutant line therefore affords us an opportunity to investigate the role of the corresponding protein in mechanoelectrical transduction.
dc:source.dc:creator: Gleason MR
dc:source.dc:title: The transmembrane inner ear (Tmie) protein is essential for normal hearing and balance in the zebrafish.

evidence.rdfs:label: Deaf Zebrafish with TMIE variant mechanotransduction study

evidence.dc:description: Used microphonic recordings to find that the potentials evoked by vibration of the inner ear with a glass probe and found that mutants lacked the typical responses at a frequency twice that of the stimulus.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish with deafness-causing TMIE variant

evidence.dc:description: Mechanotransduction in hair cells is critical to hearing loss. Restoring TMIE expression with injectoperation rescued mechanotransductive properties of TMIE deficient hair cells. They conclude that TMIE deficient hair cells are an acute phenomenon that is not caused by developmental hair cell defects.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mechanotransduction rescue in TMIE deficient mice

evidence.dc:description: Observed cochlear expression of TMIE, found that hearing in the spinner mouse was impaired and that TMIE was not present in spinner mouse. Also, used microscopy to show the disorganization of spinner sensory OHC's and stererocilia.
evidence.rdfs:label: Spinner Mouse Genotyping/Hearing/Microscopy

evidence.detectionMethod: Sequenced the four exons of TMIE from affected individuals in families demonstrating linkage to DFNB6.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: autosomal recessive sensorineural hearing loss, no vestibular dysfunction

dc:source.dc:abstract: We have identified five different homozygous recessive mutations in a novel gene, TMIE (transmembrane inner ear expressed gene), in affected members of consanguineous families segregating severe-to-profound prelingual deafness, consistent with linkage to DFNB6. The mutations include an insertion, a deletion, and three missense mutations, and they indicate that loss of function of TMIE causes hearing loss in humans. TMIE encodes a protein with 156 amino acids and exhibits no significant nucleotide or deduced amino acid sequence similarity to any other gene.
dc:source.dc:creator: Naz S
dc:source.dc:title: Mutations in a novel gene, TMIE, are associated with hearing loss linked to the DFNB6 locus.

evidence.rdfs:label: I-51, IV-1

evidence.detectionMethod: sequenced the four exons of TMIE from affected individuals in families demonstrating linkage to DFNB6.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: autosomal recessive sensorineural hearing loss, no vestibular dysfunction
evidence.rdfs:label: PKDF76, IV-1

evidence.detectionMethod: Used Affymetrix 10K arrays to search for regions of homozygosity. Deafness mapped to the DFNB8 locus' TMIE gene with this variant.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: nonsyndromic prelingual or congenital onset severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss with no vestibular involvement.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Using Affymetrix 10K arrays, we searched for regions of homozygosity in 51 Turkish families including at least three members with either congenital or prelingual autosomal recessive non-syndromic sensorineural hearing loss (ARNSSNHL), and identified four families whose deafness mapped to the DFNB6 locus on 3p21 containing the TMIE gene. Mutation analysis revealed the p.R84W mutation in all four families. Screening of this mutation in 254 families with ARNSSNHL, without GJB2 mutations, revealed four additional affected families. A novel mutation was found in a non-complementary marriage between a deaf couple who were homozygous for p.R84W and p.W57X, respectively with two affected children who were compound heterozygotes. Six of the TMIE families originated from southeastern Anatolia, making p.R84W a common cause of hearing loss in that region with a relative frequency of 10.3% (95% CI is 2.5-18.1%). The overall prevalence of the p.R84W mutation in ARNSSNHL in Turkey is 2.4% (95% CI is 0.7-4.0%). Genotyping of single-nucleotide polymorphisms flanking the TMIE gene revealed a conserved haplotype, suggesting a single origin for p.R84W from a common ancestor 1250 years ago (95% CI is 650-2500 years). We conclude that p.R84W could be a common mutation in other Middle Eastern populations and should be included in mutation screening offered to individuals with ARNSSNHL.
dc:source.dc:creator: Sirmaci A
dc:source.dc:title: A founder TMIE mutation is a frequent cause of hearing loss in southeastern Anatolia.

evidence.detectionMethod: Detailed sequencing methods not given.This missense variant is classified as pathogenic in Clinvar. It was not present in 150 Pakistani and 104 Indian individuals with normal hearing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: autosomal recessive sensorineural hearing loss, no vestibular dysfunction
evidence.rdfs:label: Consanguineous Pakistani family PKSR22B

evidence.detectionMethod:
TMPRSS3,
TMC1, USHIC and CDH23, we carried out concordance/
discordance tests using polymorphic microsatellite markers flanking
the genes (Table 1) in 374 families. These markers were
amplified using the polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: from a cohort of 374 families with hereditary hearing loss

dc:source.dc:abstract: Mutations in the autosomal genes TMPRSS3, TMC1, USHIC, CDH23 and TMIE are known to cause hereditary hearing loss. To study the contribution of these genes to autosomal recessive, non-syndromic hearing loss (ARNSHL) in India, we examined 374 families with the disorder to identify potential mutations. We found four mutations in TMPRSS3, eight in TMC1, ten in USHIC, eight in CDH23 and three in TMIE. Of the 33 potentially pathogenic variants identified in these genes, 23 were new and the remaining have been previously reported. Collectively, mutations in these five genes contribute to about one-tenth of ARNSHL among the families examined. New mutations detected in this study extend the allelic heterogeneity of the genes and provide several additional variants for structure-function correlation studies. These findings have implications for early DNA-based detection of deafness and genetic counseling of affected families in the Indian subcontinent.
dc:source.dc:creator: Ganapathy A
dc:source.dc:title: Non-syndromic hearing impairment in India: high allelic heterogeneity among mutations in TMPRSS3, TMC1, USHIC, CDH23 and TMIE.

evidence.rdfs:label: Ganapathy 1

evidence.dc:description: This variant was identified in multiple Indian families in a homozygous state in this study and was only present in 3/30602 South Asian alleles in gnomAD.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: autosomal recessive sensorineural hearing loss,Affected members of this family did have delayed development of independent ambulation, which may reflect an underlying vestibular defect.

evidence.dc:description: Same methods as above.Affected members of this family did have delayed development of independent ambulation, which may reflect an underlying vestibular defect. None of these mutations were detected in 150 Pakistani and 104 Indian individuals with normal hearing.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: autosomal recessive sensorineural hearing loss, no vestibular dysfunction
evidence.previousTestingDescription: This family was previously reported by this group in Fukushima et al. 1995 which identified an 18-cM interval between markers D3S1619 and D3S1766 that defined the DFNB6 locus. Calculated a LOD scores but didn't specify which score corresponded to this family.

However they do state that they sequenced the four exons of TMIE from affected individuals in families demonstrating linkage to DFNB6. This is a consanguineous Southern Indian family.  Affected patients were homozygous for the variant. (5/111626) European (non-Finnish) alleles

evidence.detectionMethod: Used Affymetrix 10K arrays to search for regions of homozygosity. Deafness mapped to the DFNB8 locus' TMIE gene with this variant.

dc:description: The TMIE gene has been associated with autosomal recessive hearing loss​ using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of 8/10/2017. This association was made using case-level data and experimental evidence. At least 8 unique variants (e.g. missense, nonsense, frameshift) have been reported in humans. TMIE was first associated with this disease in humans as early as 2002 (Naz et al.​). Association is seen in at least 8 or probands in 3 publications (PMIDs: 12145746, 19438934, 24416283). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 11 additional family members. This gene-disease association is supported by expression studies, knockout mouse models, biochemical function studies, protein interaction studies and a rescue in a mouse model (PMIDs: 25467981, 25475183, 19934034, 12140191). In summary, TMIE is definitively associated with autosomal recessive non-syndromic hearing loss. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Hearing Loss Working Group on 9/29/2017.
